articles.headline: Where Are the Start-Ups? Loss of Dynamism Is Impeding Growth
articles.snippet: The formation of companies is at an ebb, cutting off an avenue for new ideas, greater productivity and more opportunity.
articles.abstract: The formation of companies is at an ebb, cutting off an avenue for new ideas, greater productivity and more opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can the market economy still deliver prosperity?

articles.headline: The Era of Easy Money Is Ending, and the World Is Bracing for Shocks
articles.snippet: As a stock market plunge that began in the United States spread globally, the wild swings underscored how the American economy retains defining influence across the globe.
articles.abstract: As a stock market plunge that began in the United States spread globally, the wild swings underscored how the American economy retains defining influence across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mere days ago, in what feels like a different era now, the biggest thing that people in control of money appeared to fear was complacency. Stock markets in the United States were surging, enthralled by the regulation-slashing, tax-shrinking predilections of President Trump. Every major economy in the world was expanding.

articles.headline: So It’s Your First Market Hiccup. What Should You Do Now?
articles.snippet: Tempted to sell? Answer these six questions first, including ones about your timing, your goals, your predictive skills and your overall anxiety level.
articles.abstract: Tempted to sell? Answer these six questions first, including ones about your timing, your goals, your predictive skills and your overall anxiety level.
articles.lead_paragraph: We’ve been here before. Stocks can fall fast and bounce back hard, even if they haven’t moved all that much or that quickly in recent years.

articles.headline: Poland’s ‘Death Camp’ Law Tears at Shared Bonds of Suffering With Jews
articles.snippet: The president signed a law making it a crime to blame “the Polish nation” for the crimes of Nazi Germany. Scholars say it could whitewash history.
articles.abstract: The president signed a law making it a crime to blame “the Polish nation” for the crimes of Nazi Germany. Scholars say it could whitewash history.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — When the Nazis looked to build Auschwitz, the most notorious death camp of the Holocaust, they chose this out-of the-way village that had been home to a Polish Army barracks.

articles.headline: Volatility Rattles Stocks, and Investors Who Bet on a Continuing Calm
articles.snippet: Banks have created a variety of risky funds that allow investors to wager against sharp swings in the value of stocks. Those investors are starting to feel some pain.
articles.abstract: Banks have created a variety of risky funds that allow investors to wager against sharp swings in the value of stocks. Those investors are starting to feel some pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: As stocks maintained their smooth and steady climb in recent years, few trades were as alluring, or as profitable, as a bet that volatility as measured by Wall Street’s so-called fear gauge had vanished.

articles.headline: Trump’s Latest Surprise: Shutdown Might Be a Good Idea
articles.snippet: The president has said so many outrageous things that his latest outbursts no longer shock, but seem more of the same.
articles.abstract: The president has said so many outrageous things that his latest outbursts no longer shock, but seem more of the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week ago, President Trump stood before Congress as an improbable unifier. “Tonight,” he declared, “I call upon all of us to set aside our differences, to seek out common ground and to summon the unity we need to deliver for the people.”

articles.headline: For Korea Inc., Money and Politics Make an Awkward Olympics
articles.snippet: The Winter Games are heading to Pyeongchang at a time of reckoning about South Korea’s family-run business empires, some of which are Olympic sponsors.
articles.abstract: The Winter Games are heading to Pyeongchang at a time of reckoning about South Korea’s family-run business empires, some of which are Olympic sponsors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Wherever they are held, the Olympics are a chance for big-name local sponsors to show home-country pride, associate their brands with athletic values and splash their logos before millions of eyeballs.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Park Jeong-Eun

articles.headline: As Trump Wavers on Libya, an ISIS Haven, Russia Presses On
articles.snippet: In the absence of a coherent American policy for Libya, Russia is gaining influence in one of the most dangerous parts of the world.
articles.abstract: In the absence of a coherent American policy for Libya, Russia is gaining influence in one of the most dangerous parts of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last March, the Pentagon’s top general for Africa made a rare trip to Capitol Hill, bearing a sobering double-barreled warning.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Crazy Idea for Funding Local News: Charge People for It
articles.snippet: How two tech-industry news sites, The Information and Stratechery, may show a path forward.
articles.abstract: How two tech-industry news sites, The Information and Stratechery, may show a path forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could almost hear the trumpets blaring in the background of Mark Zuckerberg’s announcement last week that Facebook would now promote local news stories in its news feed.

articles.headline: Angela Merkel Strikes New Deal With Old Partners, at a High Cost
articles.snippet: The agreement, subject to the approval of members of the Social Democratic Party, came at a steep price for the Christian Democrats: giving up the powerful Finance Ministry.
articles.abstract: The agreement, subject to the approval of members of the Social Democratic Party, came at a steep price for the Christian Democrats: giving up the powerful Finance Ministry.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After more than four months of tortuous negotiations, with her fate and Germany’s hanging in the balance, Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday announced a deal for a new government.

articles.headline: Senate Leaders Reach Budget Deal to Raise Spending Over Two Years
articles.snippet: The agreement would raise caps on military and domestic spending, clearing the way for lawmakers to pass a spending bill for the rest of the fiscal year.
articles.abstract: The agreement would raise caps on military and domestic spending, clearing the way for lawmakers to pass a spending bill for the rest of the fiscal year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders struck a far-reaching bipartisan agreement on Wednesday that would add hundreds of billions of dollars to military and domestic programs over the next two years while raising the federal debt limit, moving to end the cycle of fiscal showdowns that have roiled the Capitol.
